awd_titl_txt: CAREER: From Substrate to Surface: Quantifying the Impact of Aquatic Vegetation on Exchange Processes
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to understand the effects of flow and vegetation on gas transfer in natural waters, from the water-sediment interface to the water surface. Understanding such processes, from substrate to surface, will allow development of process-based models for management and restoration of wetlands, estuaries, and vegetated coastal areas, and will inform models of global greenhouse gas fluxes in natural waters. The research effort addresses challenges at the interface of Geomorphology, Ecology, and Fluid Dynamics. It is coupled with an education and outreach plan that will foster a STEM-oriented, school-to-college pipeline for at-risk young boys; and will develop advanced but accessible educational material for Universities, agencies, and policy makers dealing with floodplains, wetlands, and coastal areas worldwide.

The project seeks integration of the various impacts of aquatic ecosystems in sediment and oxygen dynamics in natural waters. An extensive experimental study, using quantitative flow imaging, acoustic, and optical sensors, will fully characterize coupled water-air-vegetation-sediment interactions, by monitoring turbulent flows, sediment-oxygen demand, and their impact on gas transfer. The four unique, state-of-the-art laboratory facilities to be used will recreate unidirectional and oscillatory flow conditions at a wide range of spatial and temporal scales, representative of streams, wetlands, and coastal areas.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our study allowed us to identify and properly quantify the impact of aquatic vegetation on sediment and gas transfer dynamics. We developed process-based models for prediction of suspended sediment concentration driven by vegetation-generated turbulence, as well as predictors of gas transfer based on the effects of both submerged and emergent aquatic vegetation. Through extensive laboratory experiments, we showed that vegetation-generated turbulence is one of the main drivers of these processes, and that their inclusion in predictive models is indispensable to properly identify changes due to ecohydraulic interactions. We also produced a unique dataset on suspended sediment concentration and oxygen dynamics in unidirectional and oscillatory flows across a broad range of laboratory scales. Coupled with the now published models for suspended sediment concentration and dissolved oxygen dynamics, our openly available data will be a significant contribution to assess the impact of vegetation in aquatic ecosystems' health.

Our study provided both theoretical and practical advances. The detailed characterization of the velocity fields showed a clear effect on velocity, turbulence, and stresses across vegetated and non-vegetated layers, which result in enhancement of mixing and transport. The sediment studies showed that the effect of vegetation on sediment resuspension needs to be assessed in tandem with the bedforms enhanced or dampened within vegetation arrays, as ripple-generated turbulence can overpower the vegetation-generated turbulence under specific circumstances. The turbulence predictions near the bed and at the top of a vegetation canopy allow for translational research as we can now make hydrodynamic evaluations based on limited data from the field using our findings from the laboratory. The predictions for gas transfer rates affected by vegetation-generated turbulence allow for a more accurate quantification of storage and exchange of climate-relevant gases across the sediment-air-water interfaces. Overall, the models produced through our study have the goal to be implemented in process-based strategies for: a) management and restoration of wetlands, estuaries, and vegetated coastal areas, and b) inform models of global greenhouse gases fluxes in natural waters. 

With respect to broader impacts, the integrative approach of our Substrate-to-Surface theme allowed us to work at the interface of Geomorphology, Ecology, and Fluid Dynamics. We tackled fundamental processes to inform global greenhouse fluxes models including the complex turbulence features generated in vegetated flows to rely on more accurate process-based predictions. We have established a presence on international conferences to show the findings from our project to increase visibility of ecohydraulics laboratory work and promote interactions with a diverse group of researchers. As part of our educational component, we have trained graduate and undergraduate students in the use of state-of-the-art experimental techniques, data analysis, and technical writing, and have created a continuing and sustainable collaboration engaging with K-12 students to showcase opportunities in STEM and the paths to future multidisciplinary careers. We developed hands-on laboratory modules for existing graduate and undergraduate courses at UIUC to provide students opportunities to apply critical thinking and design criteria to engineering challenges focused on nature-based solutions.
